channel.title: Learning Java
channel.description:
Hey MoparScape,
I've been coding for RSPS for about 2 years and haven't achieve anything. I'm still really bad a java and I'm sick of it, I want to be an awesome coder and I'm really determined to do so, I am up for anything to learn at rapid fast levels and want to start coding RuneScape scripts again. I am also planning on making an awesome server that is one of the best around but for this I need to be like a Java Guru to actually master what I plan on doing. There's just so many things to learn in Java and I really want to learn but I'm struggling and finding it hard to learn, me reading Oracle websites and java tutorials on the java website is pointless because It doesn't sink in and is a bad way for me to learn. I want an effective way to learn java and to start coding and become another one of MoparScapes great coders. Please hit me up with a post or a Private Message I'd really like someone to speak to.
Thanks,
Skyro.

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

@ the blue pelican looks pretty good actually will look into it more. I have a feeling though even putting stuff in simpler terms will be harder said than done.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“whackatre, post:24, topic:441914”][quote author=t4 link=topic=544579.msg3998256#msg3998256 date=1337572587]

I recommend the Blue Pelican Java Textbook. They explain everything in simple terms, so it sticks in your head, and they have exercises (Questions) after every chapter to confirm that you understand. The book is a pretty good length too, with all you will ever need to know. The best part is, it’s free.

http://www.bluepelicanjava.com/

wow, their site looks straight out of 1999

edit: http://www.bluepelicanjava.com/author.htm rofl

What’s wrong with the author?

well, he’s not really what i would consider to be a good teacher in regards to learning proper techniques
[/quote]

but dud he has a pilot’s license and he served in the army so he must be an expert coder rite?

Lol. But really, it was funny when he put Java twice there.[/quote]
and the other things… vb, etc

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Learn ALL of the statements first.
Then static context and object-oriented programming. (constructing, etc)
I think the best help you can get is Eclipse as it provides you the documents on every method, JDK library class, etc.
Looking through existing programs (or RS servers) and learning how they function can also be a great help.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

The only downside is the improper implementations some kids come up with in this community. So when someone else looks at it (who is new) they believe that is the correct way of doing so. RSPS is a great intro into the language… but should be exercised correctly.

Read full topic

item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

Write frameworks from scratch to understand networking, and to get some practice in writing server designs

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

Thanks everyone for being so helpful, I’m going to try and I’ll get back to this topic.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

read the docs (as boring as it is), then do a practical based on what you read, e.g HelloWorld (i know you already know it):

then create a basic program out of it (in eclipse). then do this for everything you read, like arrays… etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“whackatre, post:6, topic:441914”]OK, use this checklist for a start:

Hello World
Arithmetic
String Manipulation
Arrays
File I/O
Generics/Collections
2D Graphics
Reflection
Networking
SQL
Threading[/quote]you evidently don’t understand specialisation if you’re putting 2D graphics before concurrency

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

your problem is you’re using rsps as an exercise to learn a language. this isn’t a completely bad idea if you’re starting from scratch, however.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

OK, use this checklist for a start:

Hello World
Arithmetic
String Manipulation
Arrays
File I/O
Generics/Collections
2D Graphics
Reflection
Networking
SQL
Threading

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

@Onix: As I said, reading java docs and things just doesn’t click for me. They don’t sink in and it’s a waste of hours when i could be doing something much more effective that I currently am not doing.

@Whackatre: I like that you’ve given me your luck and you’ve asked me some questions. To tell you the truth, I think I’m at skill level 1 / 99 and am not learning anything at the moment because I don’t know what to start with.

@OP: Please give me more helpful posts to read and try and use them to perform better.

Read full topic

item.title: Learning Java
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

What skill level are you currently at? What are you learning in Java currently?

Try to stay away from private servers, I found out that it helps for me.

I like your determination. Good luck!

Read full topic
